item.title: Long Tiny Loop: Attempt #2
item.description: Introduction Earlier this year, my goal was to get a Long Tiny Loop score 30.0 or greater. I ended up falling short with a 29.

item.title: The Quantified Bike Explore
item.description: There are few things I find consistently more enjoyable than exploring my surroundings from the perspective of a bicycle. Whether it’s big cities or narrow country roads, there are details which can only be experienced from this perspective.

item.title: Long Tiny Loop: Attempt #1
item.description: Introduction I’m not exactly sure how I initially came across LongTinyLoop.com, but all I know is that it checks all the right boxes for me.

item.title: Making STL frontal area calculations easier
item.description: Introduction When working with aerodynamic properties such as drag, it’s common practice to normalize these values against some sort of reference area.

item.title: Improved routing for OSMnx with Taxicab
item.description: Introduction If you’ve ever worked on the geospatial side of data science or just have a passion for maps and code, you’ve probably used OSMnx.

item.title: Effective Simulated Annealing with Python
item.description: Introduction I use some form of optimization on a daily basis, whether it’s for work or personal projects. Something else I do on a daily basis is avoid simulated annealing.

item.title: Visualizing One Hundred Years of Cincinnati Maps
item.description: #map{ width: 100%; height: 600px } #date_slider_container { position: absolute; top: 124px; left: 8px; z-index: 1000; } #date_slider{ margin: 13px; height: 200px; } #selected_year{ font-size:20px; color: grey; background-color:white; font-weight: bold; position: absolute; bottom: 200px; left: 34px; border-radius: 10px; padding-right: 0.

item.title: The Visual Similarity of Movie Posters
item.description: Recently this past winter my friends and I were trying to find something to watch on one of the major video streaming services and as as usual, we were drowning in decision paralysis.

item.title: BlenderFOAM: Open-source Fluid Based Shape Optimization
item.description: Introduction I was recently cleaning out my closet and came across an old hard drive labeled "grad school". After plugging it in and exploring it for a few minutes, I came across all my old thesis stuff.

item.title: A Low Cost Approach to Improving Pedestrian Safety with Deep Learning
item.description: .plot_style line{ stroke: grey; } .plot_style path{ stroke: grey; } .plot_style text{ fill: grey; font-size: 1em; font-family:'Open Sans'; font-style:normal; font-weight:300; } POST UPDATE: Since posting this, I've received a considerable amount of interest from individuals and local city governments from across the U.

item.title: Word2vec from Scratch with Python and NumPy
item.description: Introduction Since joining a tech startup back in 2016, my life has revolved around machine learning and natural language processing (NLP).

item.title: Chili Regions of Cincinnati [two year update]
item.description: Roughly two yeas ago I wrote my first post on here, in which I created a voronoi diagram depicting the chili regions of Cincinnati.

item.title: The Beautiful Commute: Visualizing one full year of bike commuting in Cincinnati
item.description: Introduction 2017 was an interesting year in terms of my daily commute. Although I unfortunately own a car, I refuse to waste my life mired in a quagmire of traffic like some kind of suburban commuter.

item.title: Evolving Simple Organisms using a Genetic Algorithm and Deep Learning from Scratch with Python
item.description: Introduction A few weeks ago I got pretty deep into a late night YouTube rabbit hole, and somewhere around evolving soft body robots, I came across this video (here).

item.title: Do We Actually Need to Replace the Western Hills Viaduct?
item.description: Introduction and Background If you live in the Cincinnati area, by now you should have heard that the Western Hills Viaduct is in a fairly dire situation at the moment and calls for a replacement have reached an almost fevered pitch.

item.title: Differential Evolution Optimization from Scratch with Python
item.description: Besides particle swarm optimization (PSO) which I touched on previously, differential evolution (DE) is one of my go-to favorites. Just like PSO, differential evolution falls within the evolutionary algorithms (EA) family.

item.title: The Age of Cincinnati
item.description: I’ve always been really impressed by those “age of…” maps that I see from time to time on the internet (see here, here, and here) so I thought I would give it a go this winter while I had a little free time.

item.title: Biking from Cleveland to Montréal
item.description: Earlier this summer after quitting my job I had a two week window before a mandatory bachelor party in Vegas which I was determined to fill with something good.

item.title: Calculate the Distance Between Two GPS Points with Python (Vincenty’s Inverse Formula)
item.description: Recently the work I have been doing requires a higher degree of accuracy than which the haversine method I was using could provide.

item.title: Mapping out the Southern Cultural Divide in America
item.description: I just finished the book American Theocracy by Kevin Phillips (which is a seriously good book!) but in one of the chapters they included a map showing the regions of the United States which identify as “Southern” versus “American”.

item.title: 2D Airfoil Geometry Manipulation via Composite Quadratic Bézier Curves and Python
item.description: Before any type of shape optimization can occur, the geometry needs to be parameterized (usually…). One of the easiest ways to accomplish this is through the use of Bézier curves.

item.title: Calculating the Distance Between Two GPS Coordinates with Python (Haversine Formula)
item.description: A lot of my posts recently have focused on the analysis of spatial data coming from either the GPS on my phone (collected through Strava) or geo-tagged tweets.

item.title: Montréal’s Language Distribution According to Twitter…
item.description: Over the span of roughly eight months I was able to collect 1,116,442 tweets using the Tweepy Python library which facilitates easy access to the free Twitter API.

item.title: Cincy to Dayton and Back by Bike / My First Century!
item.description: Since I had some time off recently, I decided to finally try and bike to Dayton and back in one day.

item.title: Particle Swarm Optimization from Scratch with Python
item.description: Particle swarm optimization (PSO) is one of those rare tools that’s comically simple to code and implement while producing bizarrely good results.

item.title: The White Castle/Krystal Divide
item.description: Ahh White Castle. I’ve had a love/hate relationship with this place since college. Sometimes after a solid night of pillaging and conquering, nothing satisfies your hunger like those little square, steamed devil burgers.

item.title: FiveThirtyEight: The Riddler (2016-July-08)
item.description: I hate puzzles, but for some reason I find the Riddler from FiveThirtyEight more addicting than Flavor Blasted Goldfish. Anyway, I decided to post my solution for this week.

item.title: IHOP vs. Waffle House
item.description: So I had never actually been to a Waffle House until they put the one in across from Stab and Grab in Clifton.

item.title: Dog Ownership in Cincinnati
item.description: In Cincinnati, there’s a pomeranian named Michelle Obama. There’s also a Beagle named Sarah Palin, a German Shepherd named Obwan Kenobi, and a Pit Bull Terrier named Beyoncé.

item.title: Chili Regions of Cincinnati
item.description: First post on my first blog ever! I created a voronoi diagram based off the locations of the two major chili chains in Cincinnati; Skyline and Gold Star.

item.title: About
item.description: Hi. I’m Nathan. I started out my professional career as a computational fluid dynamics (CFD) engineer doing aerodynamic design, shape optimization, and validation within the motorsport industry.

item.title: Bike Exploring NYC
